Darcy, the answer is to create a new "bogus" ebay account and use 
that to bid on the sword with. Who cares if he gives you a neg. on 
an account with little or no feedback ? 

That is what I did. 

- Matt 



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, samurai@x wrote:
> <condell@i...> writes:
> 
> > I love it.  If eBay doesn't respond I can outbid you all near 
the end
> > of the sale and either: 1. Retract my bid explaining the fraud 
causing
> > the house of cards to come tumbling down.  2. "Win" the auction, 
get
> > wire funds transfer from the "seller", and report him to the
> > authorities.
> 
> > Ideas?
> 
> Remember that a fraudulent seller if on the way out has no problem 
at
> all and nothing to lose with dinging you a negative.
> 
> Even if it is not legit, most people do not look deep enough for 
it to
> register. 
> 
> I have three negatives on my account, two from people who tried to 
scam
> me on the buying side, and one because I left a neutral on a 
seller who
> overclaimed the item he was selling. I got negatived for my 
honesty.
> 
> Anyway, the point is that it is not worth it to put yourself into a
> position to have someone put a negative comment on your feedback.
> 
> Whomever wins should act sincerely. Petitioning ebay to get a bad
> feedback item removed is a pain in the rear.
> 
> The auction will be promptly taken down if reported via the link I
> sent. I have had someone take pictures of a ring I made and put it 
up on
> ebay for $13,000.00 and it was taken down after 24 hours.
> 
> - darcy
